bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Arthur C. Jacobson, November 9, 1949

div1.p: Hench compliments Jacobson on his Reed paper. Hench inquires if Jacobson saw any records indicating that Reed examined yellow fever cases in New York.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Arthur C. Jacobson, November 9, 1949
div1.opener:
to run
yellow
fever
November 9, 1949
Dr. Arthur C. Jacobson
95 Pierrepont Street
Brooklyn 2, New York
My dear Doctor Jacobson:
div1.p:
I just received the six copies of your article this morning
and read the material this noon with great pleasure. You have
made a real contribution of the story of Reed's life and so far
as I can see you have clarified a chapter in his life which has
not been so clarified before. I am sure his friends and relatives
will appreciate this greatly.

I have already taken the liberty of sending four of your copies
to old friends of Reed, including General Kean and General Truby.
I am sure that his relatives, his son and daughter, one or two first
cousins, and other close friends would be anxious to have copies or
reprints. Should you wish to send them directly, I can later send
you their addresses or, if you care to send me a little supply of
them, I would be glad to send them out from this office with your
compliments. I am very pleased, indeed, with your whole presentation
and your remarks about my co-operation were very gracious.

There is one point that I wish you would look up if you possibly
have the time. On page 73, paragraph 5, you mentioned that cholera,
yellow fever, and smallpox had occurred in Brooklyn and you specifically
state that Reed ran into an epidemic of smallpox. Do your records
you have looked over give any substantial proof in this--that Reed
actually saw yellow fever in Brooklyn? Reed's right hand man and most
faithful associate in Cuba was Major J. R. Kean, now Brigadier General,
retired, living in Washington, D. C.. Actually, he was Reed's immediate
superior officer in Cuba. General Kean is a delightful man and a man
of phenominal accurate memory. It so happens that two or three days
before Reed landed in Cuba to begin his yellow fever work, Kean came down
with the disease himself. Reed is supposed to have rushed to the bedside
of Kean and in Kean's person he saw his first case of yellow fever.
Kean has told me this on numerous occasions--I have never questioned it.
Dr. Arthur C. Jacobson
- 2 -
November 9, 1949
I have questioned the innumerable remarks on General Kean, have
verified and sought individual verifications on all of them which
completely vindicate General Kean's beliefs and recollections.
At least, it makes a nice story and I should not like to alter it
without definite proof, but since Kean was so closely related to
Reed in Cuba and has this distinct impression, I have no doubt that
after Kean recovered Reed must have told him that he had never actually
seen a case before.

Reed had visited Cuba on previous occasions but to study other
problems and his visits were short. It is quite probable that he
never was there previously during a yellow fever epidemic. In any
event, do you recall any records indicating that Reed did see
yellow fever in New York. If you have time to follow up this study
further that would be an interesting additional point which you
might clarify.
div1.closer: Very sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:mfm
